facts.text: Appeals from judgment and order dated October 27, 1961 of Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 42 of 1961.

facts.text: Petition under Art. 226 filed by three First Grade clerks attached to offices of Collectors of Wardha, Bhandara and Chanda districts.

anchor.surface_text: petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution, filed by three First Grade clerks attached to the offices of the Collectors of Wardha, Bhandara and Chanda districts.

facts.text: Petition originally filed by two respondents as Secretary and Member of Ministerial Services Associations of Wardha and Bhandara, treated as personal petitions.

anchor.surface_text: The petition in the High Court was originally filled by two of these respondents as Secretary and Member of the Ministerial Services Associations, Wardha and Bhandara respectively but they were treated as petitions on their personal behalf.

facts.text: Petitioners sought writ of mandamus for equation of First Grade clerks posts with Aval Karkuns under ss. 115 and 116 of States Reorganization Act, 1956 and Allocated Government Servants Rules 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners asked for a writ of mandamus against the Government of Bombay for the equation of their posts with Aval Karkuns in the State of Bombay later the State of Maharashtra under ss. 115 and 116 of the States Reorganization Act, 1956 Act 37 of 1956 read with the Allocated Government Servants Absorption, Seniority, Pay Allowances Rules 1957.

facts.text: Government Resolution No. SR INT 1057/VI dated October 21, 1957 ordered First Grade clerks posts to continue on scale Rs. 80-5-130.

anchor.surface_text: Government Resolution No. SR INT 1057/VI dated October 21, 1957, together with Item No. 8 and Note 5 of the Statement accompanying that resolution, should be quashed by a writ of certiorari or by some other writ or order. By that Resolution the posts of First Grade clerks in the Deputy Commissioners offices were ordered to companytinue on the existing scale of pay of Rs. 80-5-130.

facts.text: Government Resolution No. SR INT/2159/21365-F dated October 12, 1960 fixed new pay scale Rs. 100-8-140 for petitioners' posts from May 1, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Government Resolution No. SR INT/2159/21365-F dated October 12, 1960 should be quashed inasmuch as it fixed new scales of pay Rs. 100-8-140 for the posts held by the petitioners from May 1, 1960

facts.text: Bombay High Court rejected petitioners' contention on equivalence but accepted new scales from November 1, 1956 instead of May 1, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected the companytention of the petitioners as to equivalence but accepted their companytention that the new scales of pay ought to companymence on November 1, 1956 and number May 1, 1960 as ordered by Government.

facts.text: High Court issued appropriate writs for pay scales from November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appropriate writs to effectuate the latter part of the order of the High Court issued.

facts.text: High Court certified case under Art. 132(1) and all three clauses of Art. 133.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, certified the case under Art. 132 1 and curiously enough under all the three clauses of Art. 133 of the Constitution

facts.text: States reorganisation took effect on November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: on which date the States reorganisation under the above Act took effect.

facts.text: Allocated Government Servants Absorption, Seniority, Pay Allowances Rules 1957 made by Government of Bombay under s.115 of Act and Art. 309.

anchor.surface_text: By virtue of the powers companyferred by S. 115 of the Act read with Art. 309 of the Constitution, the Allocated Government Servants Absorption, etc. Rules were made by the Government of Bombay.

facts.text: Dispute governed by rules 10 and 12 of the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The present dispute is governed by rules 10 and 12 of the Rules and we shall proceed to companysider them.

facts.text: Pay scale of First Grade clerks immediately before November 1, 1956 was Rs. 80-5-130.

facts.text: No equivalent post declared for First Grade clerks or decided unnecessary.

anchor.surface_text: the allocated Government servant who immediately before the 1st November, 1956 held at a post to which Government has number declared an equivalent post or has decided that it is number necessary to declare an equivalent post

facts.text: Duties of Aval Karkuns in former Bombay State entirely different from First Grade clerks.

anchor.surface_text: numberequivalent post was found as the duties of Aval Karkuns in the former Bombay State were entirely different from those which First Grade clerks performed.

facts.text: High Court decided against petitioners on assimilation to Aval Karkuns.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether the First Grade clerks ought to be assimilated to Aval Karkuns was decided against the three original petitioners by the High Court

facts.text: Petitioners contended Government bound to find equivalent post Aval Karkuns and rule 12 discriminatory.

anchor.surface_text: They companytend that Government was bound to find an equivalent post for them and they submit that the nearest equivalent post was that Aval Karkuns. They also companytend that by number assigning them to an equivalent post they have been discriminated against and that rule 12 which enables that a post need number be equated to an equivalent post is discriminatory.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no discrimination in not equating posts or in rule 12.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment neither submission is companyrect. There is numberquestion of discrimination because it was always possible that a special post might number fit into the kinds of. posts there were in the principal successor State.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court order that pay scales commence from November 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter the order of the High Court cancelling the date May 1, 1960 as the starting. point of the new scales of pay and fixing November 1, 1956 as. the date of start must be upheld.

facts.text: State Government's appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal of the, State Government must, therefore, stand dismissed.

facts.text: Clerks' appeal in CA No. 260 of 1964 dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the appellants in Civil Appeal No. 260 of 1964 must, therefore, fail.

arguments.claim: Rule 12 not discriminatory; provides for odd cases from multifarious posts

anchor.surface_text: A rule which provides for a special treatment of an odd case is not necessarily discriminatory. Discrimination can be proved only if equivalence is not carried out although an equivalent post is available. Rule 12 was made in view of the multifariousness of the posts existing in the different components

holdings.text: We do not think that the State Government was wrong in declining to equate the posts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Special posts may not fit; discrimination requires available equivalent not used; rule 12 valid for multifarious posts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 12 applies from November 1, 1956 for posts without equivalents; overrides prior rules but retains date.

holdings.text: In this view of the matter the order of the High Court cancelling the date May 1, 1960 as the starting point of the new scales of pay and fixing November 1, 1956 as the date of start must be upheld.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter the order of the High Court cancelling the date May 1, 1960 as the starting point of the new scales of pay and fixing November 1, 1956 as the date of start must be upheld.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules 10 and 12 require pay scales from reorganisation date; government resolution fixing later date invalid.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that the State Government was wrong in declining to equate the posts. Nor do we think that there was discrimination in doing so or Rule 12 under which it was done was discriminatory.
